commit_message:
gerritbot: send kolla/kolla-ansible stable notifications to #osism channel

OSISM is a downstream of kolla/kolla-ansible. To improve our workflow,
notifications to the stable branches should be sent to our IRC channel.
We can react better by making the changes more visible to us.

Due to the high activity in #openstack-kolla and notifications to master
on kolla/kolla-ansible/kolla-kubernetes it is very impractical for
us there.

Change-Id: I037fd07abb32659ad494f67ee9b43c25149db799

commit_message:
Add networking-sfc to periodic-stable

The networking-bagpipe's periodic-stable pipelines require
networking-sfc for its openstack-tox-py27 and
build-openstack-sphinx-docs jobs (See errors: [1] and [2])

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/periodic-stable/git.openstack.org/openstack/networking-bagpipe/stable/queens/openstack-tox-py27/024ccc3/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-03-13_06_10_55_081653
[2] http://logs.openstack.org/periodic-stable/git.openstack.org/openstack/networking-bagpipe/stable/queens/build-openstack-sphinx-docs/a2f36e0/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-03-13_06_22_51_216543

Change-Id: I7b3564d8a2819514f3be72c1cc964eb9daa5791e

commit_message:
Retire ironic-inspector-tempest-plugin

ironic and ironic-inspector both use ironic-tempest-plugin, so
ironic-inspector-tempest-plugin is not needed, nor was it ever used
(the git repo only has a .gitreview file in it).

This retires the ironic-inspector-tempest-plugin project.

This mostly follows the instructions at
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#retiring-a-project.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/550565/
Change-Id: I8dc8ce8489b38868ac712bb0aeb20ff11e094f26

commit_message:
Add #openstack-self-healing to gerritbot

We are planning to store use cases and specs in the self-healing-sig
repository.  Also monitor a few HA repositories which are inherently
related to self-healing.

Change-Id: I2f975b436f75e3aea05aee23db35778e7df2099f

commit_message:
Import config_template to openstack(-ansible)

This patch adds the config_template action plugin, coming from
OpenStack-Ansible plugins, but spined off as standalone to get
more community feedback. It's a truely generic plugin that
can be used everywhere in ansible.

An individual core group is added, but the general OSA core
group would have core capabilities as a back-stop for now, until
more diversity is found.

Needed-By: I7cbf22fff1c483f23c59cae4d9e6669f4c857f04
Change-Id: Icf63d99016c8c623a9e82b2832520c5751b3a2cd

subject: Skip sharder probe tests before starting servers
messages: [{'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-16 13:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-16 16:04:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-16 13:03:26.000000000', 'message': 'Skip sharder probe tests before starting servers

Before it would take approx 33 seconds on my laptop for a test in
probe/test_sharder.py to simply skip, because the checks for skipping
were not made until all services had been started. Now the tests will
skip in approx 23 seconds, which is less frustrating although still
not great.

Change-Id: I048d8ca83555fc225506d85887d61d8a0e7b7588
'}]
commit_message:
Skip sharder probe tests before starting servers

Before it would take approx 33 seconds on my laptop for a test in
probe/test_sharder.py to simply skip, because the checks for skipping
were not made until all services had been started. Now the tests will
skip in approx 23 seconds, which is less frustrating although still
not great.

Change-Id: I048d8ca83555fc225506d85887d61d8a0e7b7588

commit_message:
Added retries for db_sync

If db sync fails, it is never retried leading to errors. So, this
patch adds retries for db_sync to avoid sync fails.

Change-Id: I784ca2fc0a9a906633ad60d1338c4b4b73c376c7
Closes-Bug: #1628580
(cherry picked from commit c13a788dd99a515a8bc5fc52b653fead39662eb8)

In order to make it simpler to use the default
configuration files when deploying services
from source, the files are added to pbr's
data_files section so that the files are
included in the built wheels and therefore
deployed with the code. Packaging and deployment
tools can then more easily use the default files
if they wish to.

This pattern is already established with similar

Closes-Bug: #1718356

commit_message:
Add default configuration files to data_files

In order to make it simpler to use the default
configuration files when deploying services
from source, the files are added to pbr's
data_files section so that the files are
included in the built wheels and therefore
deployed with the code. Packaging and deployment
tools can then more easily use the default files
if they wish to.

This pattern is already established with similar
files for neutron, designate and glance as has
been mentioned in the related bug report.

Change-Id: Ie4277b3b94cca5c99d1e40babb085922dabcc7b0
Closes-Bug: #1718356

commit_message:
Use pod dependencies in nova chart

Changes nova chart to depend on neutron pod labels instead of daemonsets
in order to prepare for utilizing daemonset overrides in neutron chart,
Utilizes a new feature of kubernetes-entrypoint, pod dependencies, added
to kubernetes-entrypoint in v0.3.0.

Change-Id: Ic79ddc1b7f477195c5b3dfd630df4d78d7589030

messages:
[{'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2017-12-06 08:57:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2017-12-06 08:59:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I got this 502 error when I deploy glance with stable pike. The upper requirements for Webob in Pike is 1.7.3. So I think we should cherry-pick this.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2017-12-07 16:21:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Clean cherry-pick.  Withholding +1 pending answer to devstack dependency question.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2017-12-26 18:40:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

This is important to allow us to move towards running all of our services under UWSGI.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2018-01-03 20:51:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

I'm fine with backporting this it's self contained and should be low risk and enables using glance under uwsgi on pike."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-03 23:33:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Thanks for the response, Mr. T.'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2018-01-04 16:43:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

I do not think we should backport any of the uwsgi changes and give perception that glance would work under uwsgi.

There is too many current issues with that (none of the tasks run with uwsgi, if workers set to 40+ it breaks[0] and I'm likely missing some others from the list).

We're currently stronly advising not to run Glance under uwsgi and thus I don't think it's appropriate to backport some of these fixes to stable branch unless we get to the point where we can confidently say that it works.

[0] http://paste.openstack.org/show/637738/"}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2018-01-04 19:16:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Erno so your objection to backporting this is that the tasks api doesn't work with uwsgi (which is bug, but honestly very few people use). That's something I hope to have time to investigate and fix in the near future. But I don't think that alone is a reason not to backport this, because there are lots of users out there who don't care about tasks but do care about deploying with uwsgi.

Your synthetic example doesn't actually contain sufficient details to understand what's going on. I also tried to reproduce it locally and it worked fine with procs set to 40. While misconfiguring the server like that did bog down my little vm (mostly because of ram exhaustion)  it didn't cause any 500s on glance calls. I think the 500 you're getting there is likely caused by some other issue that was introduced at the same time of the restart. (which is likely why it persists across the config revert) But without actually showing the stack trace in the logs I can't tell.

Also, where is it documented that "We're currently stronly advising not to run Glance under uwsgi" because that's not the impression most people get. It's used for upstream testing on every patch which is quite visible. There is a a strong desire to use this in deployments because it makes a lot of things better and easier (which is why this backport has been proposed). Personally I think as long as you don't care about the tasks API there is nothing wrong with using uwsgi. This backport just enables people to do that instead of waiting for queens.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-01-05 19:19:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Deployer input:

We're moving more towards running every thing inside uwsgi and there is a common goal in OpenStack to do that.  In addition, the documentation leads to say that it is possible

https://docs.openstack.org/glance/pike/admin/apache-httpd.html#uwsgi

The *first* paragraph starts off with:

"uwsgi
This is the current recommended way to deploy Glance with a real web server."

This is against what is being brought up in the review, also, I believe that this backport does not impact users who are not using uwsgi.  So there is only good that can come out of it (fixing something which is claimed to be supported by the application).

If the tasks API is not working, then it would be a bug that would have to be fixed (and backported IMHO, because Glance was released with "uwsgi is the production server" so anything that affects that should be a bug).

I understand the resources or time to put into resolving this aren't always there, but at least this can move us forward in the right direction.  We have been running Glance with this patch in production for all our public and private clouds under UWSGI with no issues (we don't use the tasks API).  The cloud is quite busy and it hasn't missed a beat.'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2018-01-09 14:56:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hmm-m interestingly it seems that the stand is not as clear as I assumed. I expected to see patches to revert the devstack uwsgi deployment already by now, which clearly isn't the case.

@Mohammed thanks for the docs link, that's something we want to address sooner than later.

@Matt I do understand your interest to get this in and I'll drop my -2 on it as we don't seem to be as clear about this as I thought, but you might want to drop your +2 on your own patch ;)"}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2018-01-09 19:47:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This isn't my patch. I did write the commit on master originally, but I had nothing to do with the backport. (which is why I'm not listed as the review owner in gerrit) I didn't even see this review until someone pinged me on irc about it last week. I reviewed this with my stable hat on just like reviewing any other proposed backport and I think it fits the criteria for backport to pike and that's why I'm +2 on it."}, {'account_id': 14805, 'date': '2018-01-25 00:16:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

We're also in the process of deploying Pike and moving towards uWSGI for all API services. This patch fixed issues we were having when uploading images."}, {'account_id': 16710, 'date': '2018-02-08 15:19:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-02-16 15:37:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Just wanted to address this:

> If the tasks API is not working, then it would be a bug that would have to be fixed (and backported IMHO, because Glance was released with "uwsgi is the production server" so anything that affects that should be a bug).

Glance was explicitly NOT release with "uwsgi is the production server".  Please see the "Known Issues" section of the Pike release notes: https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/glance/pike.html#known-issues'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-02-16 16:19:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1 Code-Review-2

I want to make sure this does not merge until we have a chance to discuss this at the PTG.  I share Erno's concern about giving people the impression that we are fully supporting running glance under uwsgi unless we are committed to doing so.  Apparently the statement in the Pike release notes is being overlooked by a lot of people.  I've added a statement to the Queens release notes, but that will probably be overlooked by just as many people."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-02-16 16:19:33.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Workflow-1 by Brian Rosmaita <rosmaita.fossdev@gmail.com>
'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-02-23 03:42:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

notice Brian has a patch in devstack to stop deploying
Glance under uwsgi: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/545483/

Maybe we can cherry pick it to stable/pike and queens. Then this patch can be abandoned.'}, {'account_id': 23295, 'date': '2018-02-23 03:47:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-03-06 12:02:05.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandon now. Better to stop supporting uwsgi for Glance in devstack in Q, P'}, {'account_id': 16710, 'date': '2018-03-07 19:04:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

After seeing the comment from mtreinish on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/545483/ I think this was prematurely abandoned'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-03-09 09:21:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Eric B: My understanding of the PTG discussion is that the Glance team does not endorse efforts to patch glance in the stable branches so that it can be run in a configuration that is not recommended by the Glance team for production use, and which only fixes the problem for some use cases.'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2018-03-09 09:39:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yes indeed, the discussion in PTG was that we do not want to give the perception that we would be supporting Glance ran in WSGI containers on any current stable branches.

We obviously will not block any fixes to master trying to get us there, but we are not going to backport changes for this feature when it's clearly advised not to deploy Glance for production in this way."}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2018-03-12 19:53:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I understand you're position, but the problem with it is that it ignores that real people are using this already, whether it's the recommendation or not. Even if you ignore the people who have commented here and/or left a +1 vote, this is still the way that devstack deploys glance, and the way that OSA deploys from pike. That's a lot of users. This is why I'm being pinged by an increasing number of people every few days about this issue. The longer we wait the more people are going to keep asking about this. By refusing to backport this fix (which by the way is self contained and doesn't effect anything unless you run under uwsgi) you're forcing all of those users to do this out of band (which makes everyone's life more difficult), and makes pike as it sits today unusable for a large number of people. Quite frankly this seems like it should outweigh any implied recommendation for use by easily fixing a bug for all those users. It also doesn't change any of the big statements you have in the docs about the limitations of using uwsgi, since the async tasks support hasn't been fixed yet. Well except for maybe the last one: "If the ability to run Glance under uWSGI is important to you, feel free to participate in the Glance community to help coordinate and drive such an effort." which is exactly what this backport is. This kind of backport should honestly be table stakes for a stable branch, I'd be hard pressed to think of a more straightforward example that fits the stable policy.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-06 08:57:44.000000000', 'message': "Replace body_file with class to call uwsgi.chunked_read()

Since the WebOb 1.7 release webob doesn't natively support receiving
chunked transfer encoding bodies. [1] When glance is run under the
eventlet wsgi server this was fine, because eventlet will dechunk the
input on read() (or readline()) calls, so from the webob perspective
it's just a file object. However, the effort to remove the dependence
on using eventlet as the web server and deploy glance as a traditional
wsgi script we lose this mechanism. The wsgi spec doesn't provide a
consistent mechanism

When we run glance under uwsgi the uwsgi server provides an api to read
chunked data. [2] However, we need to explicitly call that api when to
dechunk the data and pass it to glance code which expects a file object.
This commit solves this issue by creating a fake file class that will
call the chunked_read() api from uwsgi on read() calls. This object is
then used if we're running the api code under uwsgi and the body has a
chunked transfer-encoding.

In conjuction with devstack change
Iab2e2848877fa1497008d18c05b0154892941589 this closes glance bug 1703856

[1] https://docs.pylonsproject.org/projects/webob/en/stable/whatsnew-1.7.html#backwards-incompatibility
[2] http://uwsgi-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Chunked.html

Partial-bug 1703856

Co-Authored-By: Chris Dent <cdent@anticdent.org>

Change-Id: Idf6b4b891ba31cccbeb53d373b40fce5380cea64
(cherry picked from commit bf7887a102ca33dd46ef24b67b07eb77154ce133)
"}]
commit_message:
Replace body_file with class to call uwsgi.chunked_read()

Since the WebOb 1.7 release webob doesn't natively support receiving
chunked transfer encoding bodies. [1] When glance is run under the
eventlet wsgi server this was fine, because eventlet will dechunk the
input on read() (or readline()) calls, so from the webob perspective
it's just a file object. However, the effort to remove the dependence
on using eventlet as the web server and deploy glance as a traditional
wsgi script we lose this mechanism. The wsgi spec doesn't provide a
consistent mechanism

When we run glance under uwsgi the uwsgi server provides an api to read
chunked data. [2] However, we need to explicitly call that api when to
dechunk the data and pass it to glance code which expects a file object.
This commit solves this issue by creating a fake file class that will
call the chunked_read() api from uwsgi on read() calls. This object is
then used if we're running the api code under uwsgi and the body has a
chunked transfer-encoding.

In conjuction with devstack change
Iab2e2848877fa1497008d18c05b0154892941589 this closes glance bug 1703856

[1] https://docs.pylonsproject.org/projects/webob/en/stable/whatsnew-1.7.html#backwards-incompatibility
[2] http://uwsgi-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Chunked.html

Partial-bug 1703856

Co-Authored-By: Chris Dent <cdent@anticdent.org>

Change-Id: Idf6b4b891ba31cccbeb53d373b40fce5380cea64
(cherry picked from commit bf7887a102ca33dd46ef24b67b07eb77154ce133)

Hello

I am following a bit the activity around Nova. 
I just discovered this WIP, and it reminds me things I am already doing for an extensible (research-oriented) VM scheduler I propose.
You can play with it online for the fun: http://btrplace.org.

We already think about different ways to declare and to integrate constraints inside a VM scheduler. So I allowing myself to give you some coarse-grain notes. Feel free to use/leave or discuss them.

The stateless field is something that is very important for the VM Scheduler. Typically because it offers a cheap alternative to live-migration: if the VM is stateless, boot a copy and once up, destroy the old one. You can find more notes about this feature here: https://github.com/btrplace/scheduler/wiki/Migration-or-Reinstantiation

"near" and "not near" refer to (anti-)affinity constraints I guess. Usually we differentiate affinity between VMs and between a VM and a node. Both are useful. From what I observed, the notion of affinity can be refined with a notion of scope: different nodes vs. different racks for example. Both granularity are meaningful in practice to enforce different level of fault tolerance to hardware failure.

The VM-node affinity can be wrap using syntactic sugar and node labeling for being concise. ("inside GPU-nodes" for example)

About the expressivity. By the end, constraints usually manipulate elements or set of elements. Having the possibility to label everything is great. Just for the example, we ship a DSL with BtrPlace to state constraints (see https://github.com/btrplace/scheduler/tree/master/btrpsl). 

Finally, user expectations, and cloud offering evolve over the time. In 2009, VMWare proposed VM-VM affinity. In 2011, EC2 proposed dedicated instances (my VMs don't share a server that host another client VMs). Later VMWare proposed VM-Node affinity then the possibility to cap the nodes capacity in 2012, ...
So, for a long term approach, I recommend you to have some kind of flexibility at the specification level: the constraints name should not be hardcoded so that proposing new constraints would not require to modify the specification format.

For example, here is what we do inside BtrPlace: https://github.com/btrplace/scheduler/wiki/JSON-Messages#json-format-for-constraints.
Just a field to get the constraint name. The rest is constraint specific. The VM scheduler will then bind the constraint name and its argument to its implementation, if supported. It is quite portable and not particularly heavyweight.

Sorry, if you found this message a bit long, especially coming from a complete stranger. But eh, I like to juggle with VMs :D

Regards
Fabien Hermenier

(1 comment)

Interesting. Some comments within.

I agree this is something that is needed but I think it's important to get more active input from people involved in the nova scheduler, the dead/paused Gantt project, and other schedulers.

One point that I think needs to be clarified is the differences and overlaps between resource orchestration, selection and consumption. I agree that the yaml in the spec looks a lot like Heat so it would help to know where the boundaries are between scheduling and orchestration. It may be that scheduling is an insufficiently accurate term (in the context of nova people sometimes like to use "placement", but that only works when think about putting VMs on compute nodes and that's just one part of the big picture).'}, {'account_id': 19273, 'date': '2016-01-13 17:18:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Interesting. Some comments within.
 > 
 > I agree this is something that is needed but I think it's important
 > to get more active input from people involved in the nova
 > scheduler, the dead/paused Gantt project, and other schedulers.
 > 
Indeed, this is the next step.
This point matters a lot to check if our spec allows to express the current features of each project-scheduler and if not, how to extend it properly.

 > One point that I think needs to be clarified is the differences and
 > overlaps between resource orchestration, selection and consumption.
 > I agree that the yaml in the spec looks a lot like Heat so it would
 > help to know where the boundaries are between scheduling and
 > orchestration. It may be that scheduling is an insufficiently
 > accurate term (in the context of nova people sometimes like to use
 > "placement", but that only works when think about putting VMs on
 > compute nodes and that's just one part of the big picture).

So first, about Heat. 
Heat integrates infrastructure and application concerns.
In my opinion, the current scheduler shall not manipulate application concerns. Basically because I don't think these informations  impact the scheduling decisions.
However, I think it shall be possible to provide the current language as the backend behind Heat the same way there will be some bindings behind the spec. If the specification language is correct, then it should be capable to handle every infrastructure concerns expressed by Heat.

Finally, indeed, scheduling is a vague term. In the literature, about the VM, we usually talk about VM placement algorithm. "scheduling" is more convenient once we integrate temporal concerns. For the network, various terms exists; virtual network embedding for example. The same about the storage I guess. "One word to fit them all" might be a challenge if we want to avoid the classical fillers like 'manager" :D'}, {'account_id': 19273, 'date': '2016-01-13 20:55:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I will enhance the "Interoperability" section to provide a more complete picture, including heat.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-01-14 00:46:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Thanks much :)'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-01-14 00:53:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

@cdent

Just to understand your idea you are basically saying that all resources will be managed by a 'tiny agent' (or something like that). That tiny agent will receive events on a message bus and either discard that event, put that event back on the message bus, or perform that event. The 'tiny agent' would be doing one of those three based on its own capabilities and/or availabile resources and such... Basically at that point everything is fully decentralized and any kind of structuring of resources seems somewhat impossible (since there is nothing establishing the layout of resources in such a system). That I think is one possible outcome of all of this, but it is also at the other extreme; there has to be some kind of middleground that can achieve some kind of layout and structure, while still enabling such a full-decentralized approach if its really what people want."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2016-01-14 11:08:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: -Code-Review

The "tiny agent" concept is kind of what I'm thinking except for this part:

> Basically at that point everything is fully decentralized and any kind  
of structuring of resources seems somewhat impossible (since there is nothing   
establishing the layout of resources in such a system).

I may be under-representing the complexity but my thinking is that any resource to which stuff is allocated or from which stuff is consumed should itself have the information that allows it to do structuring. For example: a compute node can do affinity or anti-affinity because it knows the ids of instances that are already on it and the networks it is hosting.

Doing this implies a lessening of expressiveness of some of the request constraints but I think that's a fair price to pay for scale, especially in an environment with lots of available resources.

Things, however, do get more difficult when requesting a suite of resources where if all of them can't be built then none of them should. For such things I think task coordination with rollback capability is the way to go. This assumes that it is cheap to create but then throw away resource consumption (which it should be, eventually, but probably isn't, yet).

I'm sure this all sounds very loosey goosey and speculative, and it is, but there's probably something in there worth teasing out (to find the middle ground, as you say).'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-01-14 21:29:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Cool, thanks for the explanation; let's keeping on thinking and maybe we'll find the middleground somewhere :)"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-01-15 01:34:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-01-15 01:37:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-01-15 01:41:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Verified+1

> Uploaded patch set 15.

We never discussed about namespaces and the possible need to interact explicitly with physical elements like the servers.

For example, to express a constraint stating some VMs must (not) be running on a given set of servers like in VMWare.  To express such a constraint properly, we must be able to write servers names but those names belong to a different namespace by principles so how to make a difference in the language about a job namespace and the server namespace ?

For example, in BtrPlace, every identifier prefixed by a '@' indicates a server, and the label is the server fully qualified name.

Does anyone have an idea ? Is there any existing standard in Openstack to differentiate a server name from a VM name ?"}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2016-03-11 20:03:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

I think this highlights an issue that I was hoping cross-project specs and cross-project awareness would help: People within the Nova project are often _far_ more aware of the changes and long term plans that Nova has that will impact other projects and the documents and other evidence of those plans are hard to find if you are not innately familiar with Nova.

I agree that this topic is something that should be worked on in concert with the nova scheduling people, but I think it is incorrect for the onus of discovery and inclusion to be anywhere other than on Nova people.'}, {'account_id': 19273, 'date': '2016-03-15 12:24:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

At my level, I don't care that much having these aspects discussed inside oslo or nova.
Jaypipes forwarded me some documentations about a future API to express "generic" placement constraints (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/183837). In a sense, it covers some of the aspects that are also depicted here.

We shall never duplicate the work so let's discuss about what is the role and the limit of everyone. In any case, I am working on VM placement algorithms and placement constraints since about 10 years now and it will be a pleasure to me to discuss with anyone, in any project, that is willing to enhance the placement possibilities inside OpenStack.

 > I think this highlights an issue that I was hoping cross-project
 > specs and cross-project awareness would help: People within the
 > Nova project are often _far_ more aware of the changes and long
 > term plans that Nova has that will impact other projects and the
 > documents and other evidence of those plans are hard to find if you

This may not have been clear:

> I agree that this topic is something that should be worked on in concert with the nova scheduling people, but I think it is incorrect for the onus of discovery and inclusion to be anywhere other than on Nova people.

What I mean is that I think Sean, Sylvain and probably people like me should bring the topics _here_ rather than people going into Nova. Because the end state is outside of Nova.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2016-03-15 13:44:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

I disagree. As the last 3 cycles of work here (as well as the failed scheduler fork lift) have demonstrated there are a lot of details to get right here. There are a ton of people working on this. Those people are in Nova in the subteam, and they are taking in requirements from other places.

This is pretty normal Open Source approach. Go to the heart of where people are working on a thing, learn the current state and evolution, and help adjust it there. Deciding to extract the conversation out of that community into another jurisdiction needs *substantial* justification.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-03-15 23:44:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

I agree with Chris.

I'd very much like to Sylvain and Sean and anyone else to get involved, nova isn't the only one with a scheduler *problem* (pick a better word here if u want) so the idea behind this spec was to start thinking about where we can go from here. Yes I know there is a 'car' moving in nova (let's call it the scheduler-fixing-car) but IMHO said 'car' can continue moving as it needs to. Just because that 'car' is moving (hopefully somewhere?) doesn't mean that another 'truck' can't come along and also start moving to.

People are a distributed system to (and no this spec won't create a scheduler for people, haha). In the end IMHO we need to all work on multiple specs and solutions concurrently, otherwise we will end up on the same car, unable to drive anywhere (due to lack of space/plans...) to continue that analogy. 

So yes, there are alot of things to get right, yes nova is working through things as well (great! the knowledge and experience gained there is priceless) but no I don't think we should prohibit another car/truck from also starting on the general area/problem for cross-project issues, just because one car/truck exists that is solving a similar problem in one project (unless nova as a project is going to be the thing that all other projects must request to be scheduled on, is it going to be that?). I am a pretty strong believer that if we don't work concurrently on this problem I think we as a community will eventually fail, to be honest (because mesos, kubernetes, yarn and other schedulers or systems with [container] schedulers are eating our cake while we complain about where and what)."}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2016-03-16 09:15:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

The main issue I have seen during the previous cross-project meeting is that this spec is not explaining whether the super-scheduler could be possibly returning other destinations but compute nodes.

TBC, are we discussing about a heterogenous scheduler providing resources not for instances, but for example, Cinder volume managers ?
If so, that would mean the global scheduler would be also being called by Cinder and deprecating the Cinder scheduler for example.

If not, if we're just talking about a scheduler returning destinations for instance placement like Nova does, I definitely think it's something that the main place for discussing is with the current nova-scheduler team first.

TBH, I'm not super conviced that Swift, Neutron or Cinder want a global scheduler for helping them to place their own resources, that's something we already discussed with the existing teams during the last summits.

That doesn't mean people don't want affinity with other things than compute nodes (or aggregates or whatever Nova provides). For sure, Neutron folks are wanting to provide to the existing Nova scheduler some resources for helping the instance to be placed close to a Neutron thing. That's something we agreed, that's coming in for Newton and probably Ocata, but that's still a Nova design discussion, not a cross-project thing."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2016-03-16 14:21:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Josh: With regards to your car/truck analogy we have had issues with that in the past when we end up with multiple implementations that are not fully compatible, e.g. nova-network and Neutron. So while I'm fully supportive of unconstrained thinking in this area I think pragmatically the solution needs to grow out of what's already in place. Otherwise we end up with something that's nice in theory but no deployers can switch to because it breaks compatibility."}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2016-03-23 17:58:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

If needed, one argument favouring a collaboration between schedulers or a meta one is related to the need to provide data-locality.

For example, in hyper-converged infrastructures, the storage and the compute layers are on the same nodes so it is important to place the VMs close to the place their data are'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-10-21 21:32:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

commit_message:
Super scheduling (WIP)

Start to discuss how we (as a community) can move beyond localized
scheduling and begin to think about how we can move away from this
existing model and work toward scheduling that can achieve a more
globally optimum (vs. a localized one).

Co-authored-by: Fabien Hermenier <fabien.hermenier@unice.fr>
Co-authored-by: Vilobh Meshram <vilobhmm@yahoo-inc.com>

Change-Id: I8c0676da80d78142241ba10f49a1b2aacdeb5c8f

commit_message:
Not much need to cache good, bad, unmatched

We can just compute these once and use them in the
appropriate places and then just return them after being
used instead of caching them locally inside the object
when such usage creates functions that have more state
and therefore are harder to understand/decipher.

Change-Id: I8b0a974ec31ad7fc34dca94c4a5cc765b75fd940

commit_message:

commit_message:
Use a barrier to know all threads are done vs 'unfinished_tasks'

We know how many image tasks there will be so instead of doing
a somewhat arbitrary sleep as we try to wait until all the image
tasks have been processed (by looking at the underlying queue
work) we can just use a simple barrier/latch concept that blocks
the main thread until all the images that we expect to be processed
actually are.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: Ibc7fc1ca6005cb229bdf06394eaf91a947d47358

commit_message:
Install horizon directly from pypi

It's no longer possible to install horizon with our current
method, and it's causing the ci to fail.
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128310.html

Change-Id: I5f9a3ce76c233e62ff6addcaf6d229455ac29374

commit_message:
Allow specifying glance 'registry_client_protocol'

The glance registry is not yet removed; and since it is
not it is useful to be able to specify if the glance registry
is running over https or http (the default).

Change-Id: Id9a7beb4773f2131b867b1111111f1b09ed6ca28

commit_message:
WIP: Propose to support preemptible instances

This is an incomplete proposal to add initial support preemptible
instances, to see if the idea makes sense or not as it is proposed or
not. The spec is not complete yet.

Implements: blueprint preemptible-instances
APIImpact
Change-Id: Ide101ac64afefae4597e2a191b45ac51dc2fb9bb

Change-Id: Ia8c483d34a26ba0ccfe25b5496cc03af4c1b7808
'}]
commit_message:
Adding support for RHEL images

Adding support for rhel images on the image generation system.

Note.: It is necessary to previous to start packing the image for the
user to register the image using virt-costumize and also enable the
necessary REPOS.

Change-Id: Ia8c483d34a26ba0ccfe25b5496cc03af4c1b7808

commit_message:
Add 'Other considerations' to security doc

This adds an 'Other considerations' section to the Security
documentation to include things that may not merit their
own section.

Change-Id: Ic4a854a9fb8e12e0d6cdf969ef804e25f6341a32
Related-bug: #1659455
Related-bug: #1692511
Co-Authored-By: Ruby Loo <ruby.loo@intel.com>

commit_message:
Remove kuryr legacy job and move the Zuulv3 one to experimental gate

As current kuryr job is not even installing networking-ovn nor kuryr,
this patch is removing it. Even if we decide to fix it [0], its value
is still unclear since we would be depending on more projects and
we would have to run kuryr's tempest tests instead of ours.

As kuryr folks are setting up a new job to their gate using OVN as
a backend [1], let's remove this job from networking-ovn gate for now
and run their Zuulv3 job to the experimental pipeline.

Closes-bug: #1748857

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/543419/
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/543864/

Change-Id: Iea69d16a6ae919404987643732ee3ac6582c31a7
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Correct application credential usage doc

There is a --restricted flag to counter the --unrestricted flag. It was
documented, but the usage example had missed it. Add it for
completeness.

Change-Id: Ib4cdcacdd16bfb59e9d18714106ecda99e418812

commit_message:
Removed unnecessary parantheses in yield statements

The 'yield' statement is not a function.
So it must always be followed by a space when yielding a value.

Change-Id: Ie2aa1c4822d8adf721ba71d467b63209bede6fb7

subject: Added spec for splitting common requirements into driver-specific
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 1736, 'name': 'Ivan Kolodyazhny', 'email': 'e0ne@e0ne.info', 'username': 'e0ne'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4146, 'name': 'Clark Boylan', 'email': 'cboylan@sapwetik.org', 'username': 'cboylan'}, {'_account_id': 4190, 'name': 'lifeless', 'email': 'robertc@robertcollins.net', 'username': 'lifeless'}, {'_account_id': 5638, 'name': 'Davanum Srinivas', 'email': 'davanum@gmail.com', 'username': 'dims-v'}, {'_account_id': 6928, 'name': 'Ben Nemec', 'email': 'openstack@nemebean.com', 'username': 'bnemec'}, {'_account_id': 7102, 'name': 'Thomas Bechtold', 'email': 'thomas.bechtold@canonical.com', 'username': 'toabctl'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 8415, 'date': '2015-02-09 09:52:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-02-09 10:07:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-oslo-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/66/153966/1/check/gate-oslo-specs-docs/9b15012//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 3m 23s'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2015-02-12 22:20:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

Let me start by saying that we should solve this so that we don't rely purely on documentation as the way to figure out how to install a dependency that may not be required in every case.

However, I have a preference for just requiring packages if actual functionality depends on these packages. The example I have used in the past is oslo.messaging should just install the messaging libs it needs for zmq and amqp and so on. The reason for this is user friendliness. As a user I may not know that I will want some other feature enabled in the future and if I have to go through a debug process to figure out why it doesn't work after enabling it I will be unhappy. If optional deps are this complicated for us it will only be worse for our users.

I get that this can cause some headaches for developers who have to install mysqlclient dev headers or the postgres client dev headers so that both sets of python client libs can be built, but developers know how to deal with these problems.

As an additional "data" point even Debian installs Recommended packages by default now, blurring the line between required and optional packages on Debuntu systems.

Thats my preference, but I also think the extras_require option is workable as well. I have left a couple inline comments that more directly address that portion of this spec.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2015-02-13 19:17:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

One thought I had about this is to make the optional dependencies opt-out instead of opt-in.  So install everything by default, but have a way to say "I don't want zmq or qpid in my rabbitmq deployment" and vice versa.  I could see this being useful for things like devstack where you know ahead of time what people will be using, and they'll need to restack to switch drivers anyway.

This would make the default simple, if excessive, but allow users who know what they're doing to pare down the requirements list.  In fact, looking at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/83150/ I see that already appears to be what Denis has done.

I know one of the other concerns about this was that we're making OpenStack diverge from what the rest of the Python community is doing, but with the current proposal we're using all upstream features of setuptools and pip to do this:

 1) -r for nested requirements files
 2) extras_require for specifying which drivers to install

The only major thing I see missing is that pip apparently doesn't support extras yet: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4796936/does-pip-handle-extras-requires-from-setuptools-distribute-based-sources

I'm also a little unclear on how that would work with the opt-out method, but I would think we can work with upstream to figure that out.

Anyway, those are my current thoughts.  I would love to hear from some of the other people who have weighed in on this in the past so we can figure something out that will make everyone happy (or at least not-unhappy... ;-).'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2015-02-23 21:43:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

Some interesting ideas. I've left a few questions inline."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2015-03-12 19:39:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2015-05-01 14:35:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

not sure if we have incorporated feedback from mailing lists. Also needs to move from kilo to liberty'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2015-05-01 14:35:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

http://markmail.org/message/x24w3mxbme4hdge7 etc'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2015-05-15 13:56:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Denis, ping'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2015-06-01 19:46:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-03-16 20:07:30.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

I think this has been adequately addressed by pip extras and the review is extremely old.  If there is any further work required on this topic we should have a new spec.'}]

commit_message:
Avoid tox-install.sh

Instead of using tox-install.sh, we can install horizon and neutron
now directly from pypi - or use the current branch in CI system using
tox-siblings.

Update tox.ini for this change and add neutron to requirements file.

Change-Id: I29c17d51f2648e4bdef1a8c9799ca5e785aa3423

commit_message:
Add Ceph upgrade steps for FFU

Currently we need to run the Ceph upgrade in an additional step. This
change adds the ceph upgrade step during the FFU procedure.

In addition it moves the ceph parameters convert script to common directory
as it is not used by current upgrade anymore.

Change-Id: I38ae845445e26518923a1b711b10f93914c29e69

commit_message:
check LIBS_FROM_GIT

after the glance_store vs. upper-constraints bug, it's probably worth
actually enforcing and sanity checking that devstack is doing what
it's being asked of with LIBS_FROM_GIT. This will hopefully reduce
user generated error.

This *might* not work with the current oslo naming, we'll have to test
and normalize that.

Change-Id: Iffef2007f99a0e932b68c4c897ebbfb748cac2b4

[{'created': '2018-03-16 14:25:09.000000000', 'message': 'Add note to keystone-manage bootstrap doc

A lot of people are very surprised that we no longer reference port
35357 in our Ubuntu (and SUSE) install guides. Add a note to clarify
that this is not a bug and we do really mean it.

This does not change the RDO install guide because our guide still
instructs users to use port 35357 because the RDO package still includes
an Apache vhost file that uses 35357.

Change-Id: I334ba888190705a345d50cebe577b832753f202c
Related-bug: #1755026
Related-bug: #1755511
Related-bug: #1756178
'}]
commit_message:
Add note to keystone-manage bootstrap doc

A lot of people are very surprised that we no longer reference port
35357 in our Ubuntu (and SUSE) install guides. Add a note to clarify
that this is not a bug and we do really mean it.

This does not change the RDO install guide because our guide still
instructs users to use port 35357 because the RDO package still includes
an Apache vhost file that uses 35357.

Change-Id: I334ba888190705a345d50cebe577b832753f202c
Related-bug: #1755026
Related-bug: #1755511
Related-bug: #1756178

commit_message:
Fix assert test error under py3.6

The function __str__ of class subprocess.CalledProcessError
is different between py3.6 and lower python version.

        py3.6: Command '%s' returned non-zero exit status %d.
lower version: Command '%s' returned non-zero exit status %d

There is a . in py3.6.

This patch fix the assert error under py3.6

Change-Id: I19ae5711ed7440791583940fa4a8fb770dcdc933
Closes-bug: #1751551

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-05 01:35:26.000000000', 'message': "Fix mysql connection

URL mysql://scott:***@some_host/some_db does not contain a '+drivername'
portion, and will make use of a default driver. A full dbname+drivername://
protocol is recommended. For MySQL, it is strongly recommended that
mysql+pymysql:// be specified for maximum service compatibility.

Change-Id: Ib5cbfcc412c04381f2fce9f319a313eb86ea7fa8
Closes-Bug: #1753342
"}]
commit_message:
Fix mysql connection

URL mysql://scott:***@some_host/some_db does not contain a '+drivername'
portion, and will make use of a default driver. A full dbname+drivername://
protocol is recommended. For MySQL, it is strongly recommended that
mysql+pymysql:// be specified for maximum service compatibility.

Change-Id: Ib5cbfcc412c04381f2fce9f319a313eb86ea7fa8
Closes-Bug: #1753342

commit_message:
Configure additional properties

Configure the 'html_last_updated_fmt', 'latex_engine' and
'latex_elements' attributes automatically. Documentation is updated to
reflect the fact that these no longer need to be configured by hand.

Change-Id: I429b981135e35845bf5ed70020abfef3deccbf90

'}, {'created': '2018-03-14 21:10:50.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Refine waiting for vif plug events during _hard_reboot"

This gets us back to Ib0cf5d55750f13d0499a570f14024dca551ed4d4
which was meant to address an issue introduced
by Id188d48609f3d22d14e16c7f6114291d547a8986.

So we essentially had three changes:

1. Hard reboot would blow away volumes and vifs and then wait for the
   vifs to be plugged; this caused a problem for some vif types (
   linuxbridge was reported) because the event never came and we
   timed out.

2. To workaround that, a second change was made to simply not wait for
   vif plugging events.

3. Since #2 was a bit heavy-handed for a problem that didn't impact
   openvswitch, another change was made to only wait for non-bridge vif
   types, so we'd wait for OVS.

But it turns out that opendaylight is an OVS vif type and doesn't send
events for plugging the vif, only for binding the port (and we don't
re-bind the port during reboot). There is also a report of this being a
problem for other types of ports, see
If209f77cff2de00f694b01b2507c633ec3882c82.

So rather than try to special-case every possible vif type that could
be impacted by this, we are simply reverting the change so we no longer
wait for vif plugged events during hard reboot.

Note that if we went back to Id188d48609f3d22d14e16c7f6114291d547a8986
and tweaked that to not unplug/plug the vifs we wouldn't have this
problem either, and that change was really meant to deal with an
encrypted volume issue on reboot. But changing that logic is out of the
scope of this change. Alternatively, we could re-bind the port during
reboot but that could have other implications, or neutron could put
something into the port details telling us which vifs will send events
and which won't, but again that's all outside of the scope of this
patch.

commit_message:
Revert "Refine waiting for vif plug events during _hard_reboot"

This gets us back to Ib0cf5d55750f13d0499a570f14024dca551ed4d4
which was meant to address an issue introduced
by Id188d48609f3d22d14e16c7f6114291d547a8986.

So we essentially had three changes:

1. Hard reboot would blow away volumes and vifs and then wait for the
   vifs to be plugged; this caused a problem for some vif types (
   linuxbridge was reported) because the event never came and we
   timed out.

2. To workaround that, a second change was made to simply not wait for
   vif plugging events.

3. Since #2 was a bit heavy-handed for a problem that didn't impact
   openvswitch, another change was made to only wait for non-bridge vif
   types, so we'd wait for OVS.

But it turns out that opendaylight is an OVS vif type and doesn't send
events for plugging the vif, only for binding the port (and we don't
re-bind the port during reboot). There is also a report of this being a
problem for other types of ports, see
If209f77cff2de00f694b01b2507c633ec3882c82.

So rather than try to special-case every possible vif type that could
be impacted by this, we are simply reverting the change so we no longer
wait for vif plugged events during hard reboot.

Note that if we went back to Id188d48609f3d22d14e16c7f6114291d547a8986
and tweaked that to not unplug/plug the vifs we wouldn't have this
problem either, and that change was really meant to deal with an
encrypted volume issue on reboot. But changing that logic is out of the
scope of this change. Alternatively, we could re-bind the port during
reboot but that could have other implications, or neutron could put
something into the port details telling us which vifs will send events
and which won't, but again that's all outside of the scope of this
patch.

Change-Id: Ib3f10706a7191c58909ec1938042ce338df4d499
Closes-Bug: #1755890

commit_message:
Revert "Refine waiting for vif plug events during _hard_reboot"

This gets us back to Ib0cf5d55750f13d0499a570f14024dca551ed4d4
which was meant to address an issue introduced
by Id188d48609f3d22d14e16c7f6114291d547a8986.

So we essentially had three changes:

1. Hard reboot would blow away volumes and vifs and then wait for the
   vifs to be plugged; this caused a problem for some vif types (
   linuxbridge was reported) because the event never came and we
   timed out.

2. To workaround that, a second change was made to simply not wait for
   vif plugging events.

3. Since #2 was a bit heavy-handed for a problem that didn't impact
   openvswitch, another change was made to only wait for non-bridge vif
   types, so we'd wait for OVS.

But it turns out that opendaylight is an OVS vif type and doesn't send
events for plugging the vif, only for binding the port (and we don't
re-bind the port during reboot). There is also a report of this being a
problem for other types of ports, see
If209f77cff2de00f694b01b2507c633ec3882c82.

So rather than try to special-case every possible vif type that could
be impacted by this, we are simply reverting the change so we no longer
wait for vif plugged events during hard reboot.

Note that if we went back to Id188d48609f3d22d14e16c7f6114291d547a8986
and tweaked that to not unplug/plug the vifs we wouldn't have this
problem either, and that change was really meant to deal with an
encrypted volume issue on reboot. But changing that logic is out of the
scope of this change. Alternatively, we could re-bind the port during
reboot but that could have other implications, or neutron could put
something into the port details telling us which vifs will send events
and which won't, but again that's all outside of the scope of this
patch.

Change-Id: Ib3f10706a7191c58909ec1938042ce338df4d499
Closes-Bug: #1755890

commit_message:
Carbon tempest CI fix: let ODL create br-int

To avoid this bug until it is fixed:
https://bugs.opendaylight.org//show_bug.cgi?id=8893

Note that it would be better to run with devstack
creating br-int because that is how most customers
will be using this but until the above bug is fixed
let's have a working gate.

Change-Id: I2b2b4e0e754f3d492fc0a2808272e204dac82e91
(cherry picked from commit 9942be188bc5d77a45b5bf39f8e69a4fa79c4ac8)

commit_message:
[Docs] Simplify advanced config

This merges advanced configuration and inventory, from the
operations guide into the reference guide. This avoids
duplications of the documentation accross the guides.

Change-Id: I6fd758b89a84698b0ac8e227d97cb24914bc2066
(cherry picked from commit 6435ec75210b343a359e8b524aa0967cb0b81b43)

commit_message:
[Docs] Move the upgrade reference into reference

Now that the upgrade should have moved to the operations guide,
the upgrade reference should head in th reference guide.

In order to accomodate the new data into reference, the reference
landing page now links to both inventory and upgrades.

Change-Id: Ieb3eb0627854b80a7fed532702b77a7ec9a36e64
(cherry picked from commit d5937a519f7634fd8c077c92786054f04c94e5ce)

commit_message:
[Docs] Promote scale the environment

Scale the environment deserves its own chapter.
On top of that, the managing swift section is
about how scaling is done with swift clusters
(Multi-Region handling), and therefore should
be moved into scaling the environment.

commit_message:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-11 17:37:38.000000000', 'message': 'Pin ansible at urllib fix SHA

In ansible 2.3.2.0 there is an SNI bug which is preventing deployment
in calico environments since get_url is unable to fetch packages
from github.com.

Example output of the issue:
fatal: [aio1]: FAILED! => {"attempts": 5, "changed": false, "failed": true,
"msg": "Failed to validate the SSL certificate for github.com:443. Make sure
your managed systems have a valid CA certificate installed. You can use
validate_certs=False if you do not need to confirm the servers identity but
this is unsafe and not recommended. Paths checked for this platform:
/etc/ssl/certs, /etc/pki/ca-trust/extracted/pem, /etc/pki/tls/certs,
/usr/share/ca-certificates/cacert.org, /etc/ansible. The exception msg
was: (\"bad handshake: Error([('SSL routines', 'ssl3_read_bytes',
'tlsv1 alert protocol version')],)\",)."}

Pinning to the SHA [1] fixes this issue, and it will be included in
the future 2.3.4.0 release of ansible (currently in rc1). We can
change this pin to use the 2.3.4.0 release once it is final.

Change-Id: I6f7bd8078021fb2dd2ac1978d4511c12b76d318a

commit_message:
Pin ansible at urllib fix SHA

In ansible 2.3.2.0 there is an SNI bug which is preventing deployment
in calico environments since get_url is unable to fetch packages
from github.com.

Example output of the issue:
fatal: [aio1]: FAILED! => {"attempts": 5, "changed": false, "failed": true,
"msg": "Failed to validate the SSL certificate for github.com:443. Make sure
your managed systems have a valid CA certificate installed. You can use
validate_certs=False if you do not need to confirm the servers identity but
this is unsafe and not recommended. Paths checked for this platform:
/etc/ssl/certs, /etc/pki/ca-trust/extracted/pem, /etc/pki/tls/certs,
/usr/share/ca-certificates/cacert.org, /etc/ansible. The exception msg
was: (\"bad handshake: Error([('SSL routines', 'ssl3_read_bytes',
'tlsv1 alert protocol version')],)\",)."}

Pinning to the SHA [1] fixes this issue, and it will be included in
the future 2.3.4.0 release of ansible (currently in rc1). We can
change this pin to use the 2.3.4.0 release once it is final.

[1] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/commit/6020c0d4f64dbafcbafdffbfc67cfc5bb6b3c75c

Change-Id: I6f7bd8078021fb2dd2ac1978d4511c12b76d318a

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-15 13:10:35.000000000', 'message': 'Add missing Ubuntu packages

When running scripts/bootstrap-aio.sh with options set to
export BOOTSTRAP_OPTS="bootstrap_host_data_disk_device=sdb"
parted is required to cope with disk wiping and proper
partitioning. iptables are required later while configuring
vlans and bridges.

commit_message:
Add missing Ubuntu packages

When running scripts/bootstrap-aio.sh with options set to
export BOOTSTRAP_OPTS="bootstrap_host_data_disk_device=sdb"
parted is required to cope with disk wiping and proper
partitioning. iptables are required later while configuring
vlans and bridges.

Change-Id: I2221fc63c3779358dec5edf9e2d110bc2e1528c1

commit_message:
Added retries for db_sync

If db sync fails, it is never retried leading to errors. So, this
patch adds retries for db_sync to avoid sync fails.

Change-Id: I784ca2fc0a9a906633ad60d1338c4b4b73c376c7
Closes-Bug: #1628580

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-08 14:33:24.000000000', 'message': "Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I2ebdff89d8f1cf7a1475d210811093e765911ffb
"}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: I2ebdff89d8f1cf7a1475d210811093e765911ffb

Instead of using tox-install.sh, we can install horizon and neutron
now directly from pypi - or use the current branch in CI system using

Update tox.ini for this change and add neutron to requirements file.

Change-Id: Ifb0890e6d287dc24a654ac47d23cd9e1d7fb830d

commit_message:
Avoid tox-install.sh

Instead of using tox-install.sh, we can install horizon and neutron
now directly from pypi - or use the current branch in CI system using
tox-siblings.

Update tox.ini for this change and add neutron to requirements file.

Change-Id: Ifb0890e6d287dc24a654ac47d23cd9e1d7fb830d

commit_message:
FFU: Introduce post FFU steps and use them for qeens switch

In last step of FFU we need to swich repos before running upgrade.
We do so by introducing post FFU steps and running the switch in
them. We also update heat agents and os-collect-config on nodes.

Change-Id: I649afc6fa384ae21edc5bc917f8bb586350e5d47

commit_message:
Introduce inspect wait state

The in-band inspection is an asynchronous process isn't currently
handled through a "waiting" state. This is a discrepancy from the
rest of the asynchronous ironic states and may comprise a problem
for future features such as aborting the introspection or merging
ironic and ironic-inspector.

The spec adds a new inspect wait state to ironic state machine to
keep consistent with other asynchronous states.

Change-Id: I6fe864079d85fe7e7ba9650a51628e88e8a662cc
Partial-Bug: #1725211

[{'created': '2018-03-10 15:45:20.000000000', 'message': "Fix typo and misleading task name for nova-consoleauth

The services for console are installed in the 'Install nova
console/metadata services' task, however, the scheduler
install task misleadingly is named to mention that it installs
consoleauth and tries to run on the nova_consoleauth group
which does not exist.

Change-Id: If7c00cbfe3bd50a3702f86e7348de206b9fa3b95
"}]
commit_message:
Fix typo and misleading task name for nova-consoleauth

The services for console are installed in the 'Install nova
console/metadata services' task, however, the scheduler
install task misleadingly is named to mention that it installs
consoleauth and tries to run on the nova_consoleauth group
which does not exist.

Change-Id: If7c00cbfe3bd50a3702f86e7348de206b9fa3b95

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-24 16:44:33.000000000', 'message': "Replace host_need_pip with standard override mechanism

The variable host_need_pip is currently used to be selective
about when pip is installed on the target hosts/containers.

This is an unnecessary precaution given that if the repo
container is not yet up, there is already a mechanism in place
to detect this and override the constraint and get-pip script
URL. By using this mechanism we get pip installed very early
and pip's configuration is still correctly constrained.

This patch ensures that this very same mechanism is used across
the board instead of using two different mechanisms, thereby
simplifying the approach.

Change-Id: I22d2f5edf640b71cb80b3fd1de597ea7391db11c
Implements: blueprint python-build-install-simplification
Signed-off-by: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>
(cherry picked from commit bc4f6ea47c325fbde1b2b70c0b3b18c4d4b95cf0)
"}]
commit_message:
Replace host_need_pip with standard override mechanism

The variable host_need_pip is currently used to be selective
about when pip is installed on the target hosts/containers.

This is an unnecessary precaution given that if the repo
container is not yet up, there is already a mechanism in place
to detect this and override the constraint and get-pip script
URL. By using this mechanism we get pip installed very early
and pip's configuration is still correctly constrained.

This patch ensures that this very same mechanism is used across
the board instead of using two different mechanisms, thereby
simplifying the approach.

Change-Id: I22d2f5edf640b71cb80b3fd1de597ea7391db11c
Implements: blueprint python-build-install-simplification
Signed-off-by: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>
(cherry picked from commit bc4f6ea47c325fbde1b2b70c0b3b18c4d4b95cf0)

subject: [Docs] Simplify and fix docs configuration
messages: [{'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-03-15 14:44:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-03-15 14:45:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nI will apply the same reasoning for the deploy-guide docs in a different patchset.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-03-16 08:47:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2018-03-16 12:10:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-15 14:44:17.000000000', 'message': "[Docs] Simplify and fix docs configuration

The documentation has currently multiple problems:
- The top left tag of the openstacktheme isn't consistent with
  the latest available tag, which confuses people (see
  related bug)
- There are unused variables that could deserve cleanup
- There are static content that can be discovered from files
- We don't leverage the dynamic nature of the configuration for
  conditional upgrade messages, while we should.

Change-Id: If8776ee54fda5cdcc27be36e2031150914aa32b2
Related-Bug: #1755241
"}]
commit_message:
[Docs] Simplify and fix docs configuration

The documentation has currently multiple problems:
- The top left tag of the openstacktheme isn't consistent with
  the latest available tag, which confuses people (see
  related bug)
- There are unused variables that could deserve cleanup
- There are static content that can be discovered from files
- We don't leverage the dynamic nature of the configuration for
  conditional upgrade messages, while we should.

Change-Id: If8776ee54fda5cdcc27be36e2031150914aa32b2
Related-Bug: #1755241

commit_message:
[Docs] Introduce next steps

To be more like a walkthrough, the next step after the
verification of the environment would be to contribute and
operate OpenStack-Ansible.

This could also bring more visibility to contributions.

Change-Id: I991ad7963bcd777e279738bb9d4ca03992f46280
(cherry picked from commit b83ffe3680711ad07dea4590c552f04bbe62c974)

commit_message:
Update the doc generation (tox, remove warnings PTI)

- isolate the doc requirements into doc/requirements.txt
  according the guidelines of the Project Testing Interface:
  https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html#documentation
  http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125710.html
  The upper-requirements.txt file is not used because
  sahara-tests is branchless.
- consistently remove the old builds before calling sphinx:
  implement it for releasenotes,
  simplify the list of directories removed for docs;
- enable warning-as-error for releasenotes and
  fix the only warning found (with a workaround,
  for some reason adding releasenotes.rst to exclude_patterns
  in conf.py did not work).

Change-Id: If0601c5e893853518cd6eb769da2be3037364dc9

commit_message:
Fix some reST field lists in docstrings

Probably the most common format for documenting arguments is reST field
lists [1]. This change updates some docstrings to comply with the field
lists syntax.

[1] http://sphinx-doc.org/domains.html#info-field-lists

Change-Id: Ic87b30963f99552e57d10e8429a06511744b2489

commit_message:
FFU: Upgrades: fix pacemaker checks

Check if pacemaker resource is defined, not if it's running.
Ensure we try disabling pacemaker resources during FFU.

Change-Id: I9be9118490a28ee9c24d9c8c89a8daee75e5b817

commit_message:
Fix gnocchi-upgrade Table <..> already exists errors

Currently we are calling /usr/bin/gnocchi-upgrade
--sacks-number=SACK_NUM from each node where gnocchi-api is part of the
role. gnocchi-upgrade seems to be racy and we sometimes end up with the
following error:

2018-03-14 12:39:39,683 [1] ERROR    oslo_db.sqlalchemy.exc_filters: DBAPIError exception wrapped from (pymysql.err.InternalError) (1050, u"Table 'archive_policy' already exists") [SQL: u'\nCREATE TABLE archive_policy (\n\tname VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL, \n\tback_window INTEGER NOT NULL, \n\tdefinition TEXT NOT NULL, \n\taggregation_methods TEXT NOT NULL, \n\tPRIMARY KEY (name)\n)ENGINE=InnoDB CHARSET=utf8\n\n']
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/sqlalchemy/engine/base.py", line 1182, in _execute_context
    context)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/sqlalchemy/engine/default.py", line 470, in do_execute
    cursor.execute(statement, parameters)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pymysql/cursors.py", line 166, in execute
    result = self._query(query)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pymysql/cursors.py", line 322, in _query
    conn.query(q)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pymysql/connections.py", line 856, in query
    self._affected_rows = self._read_query_result(unbuffered=unbuffered)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pymysql/connections.py", line 1057, in _read_query_result
    result.read()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pymysql/connections.py", line 1340, in read
    first_packet = self.connection._read_packet()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pymysql/connections.py", line 1014, in _read_packet
    packet.check_error()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pymysql/connections.py", line 393, in check_error
    err.raise_mysql_exception(self._data)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pymysql/err.py", line 107, in raise_mysql_exception
    raise errorclass(errno, errval)
InternalError: (1050, u"Table 'archive_policy' already exists")

Let's run it from a the bootstrap node by wrapping it into the
bootstrap_host_exec magic.

Change-Id: I106512eeffff3425608a543f9bc5e6a9508d15e5
Closes-Bug: #1755564

commit_message:
Add testscenarios and testresources to test reqs

We were depending on oslo.db to provide the dependencies for the
oslo_db.sqlalchemy.test_fixtures libary that we started using in our
unit tests[1]. Oslo.db since removed some of those dependencies during
its constraints cleanup[2]. This patch adds them to our own
test-requirements.txt so that they're available to us.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/531577
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/550842

Change-Id: I848a8abba91217362dcdff449730dc4e4d2ac3db

commit_message:
Convert ServiceNetMap evals to hiera interpolation

Since https://review.openstack.org/#/c/514707/ added the net_ip_map
to hieradata, we can look up the per-network bind IPs via hiera
interpolation instead of heat map_replace.

In some cases the ServiceNetMap lookup is used for other things,
but anywhere we make use of the "magic" translation via NetIpMap
is changed the same way.

This will enable more of the configuration data to be exposed per
role vs per node in a future patch (to simplify our ansible
workflow).

Co-authored-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ie3da9fedbfce87e85f74d8780e7ad1ceadda79c8

commit_message:
Config privsep in the linuxbridge agent

In order to enable arp_responder code, the agent must have
privsep configured or calls to add fdb entries will fail.

This is a one-file cherry pick of the master change referenced
below as the rest does not apply.

Closes-bug: 1754563

(cherry picked from commit e0223edf88abc8c1bb8714121a0df8a9997c7a30)

Change-Id: I80b8c02da5d769dcb7bbf6f9e4659889c7c92650

commit_message:
Remove tox_install.sh and align constraints consumption

As part of removing reliance on the old and deprecated zuul-cloner,
we need to shift constraints declaration to the deps line. This
means we unfortunately have to duplicate the extras declarations
into test-requirements - because otherwise the contraints for
oslo.db conflicts with the installation of itself.

Change-Id: I2b79444a58a9144993131f9cba7494b236d9e950

commit_message:
Add angular server groups panel

This patch adds angular server groups panel under the
project->compute panel group.

To be added in subsequent patches:
 - Create Action
 - Delete Action
 - Detais

To view the server groups panel only the 'ServerGroups' nova API
extension is available.

Change-Id: Ide9f54439c52cce9642c2dd417f9e7a8ad98e846
Implements: blueprint ng-server-groups

commit_message:
Add overcloud deployment job

Adds a Zuul job to perform deployment of an OpenStack control plane
consisting of a single node. Currently no tests are run against the
resulting control plane.

Change-Id: I2728421cb5dbd1dc370a3aa7d37d913c90ba38a5
Story: #2001655
Task: #6682

commit_message:
Add meaningful exception in Neutron port show

We had already defined an exception FailedToGetIPAddressOnPort
if not get fixed_ips, for the neutron port show we can add
some meaningful exception.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-16 13:21:10.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Rename duplicated class name AttachVolumeMultiAttachTest"

This reverts commit fdee065bc8a2309965a51d9f24e624dfd088f9bd.

There has been a spike in volume test failures since this
change merged on March 13th due to scheduling failures in
Cinder with the CapacityFilter, presumably because the rename
caused too many volume tests to be running concurrently on
the same host.

Until we have a better solution, like potentially bumping
the size of the volume group in devstack, we can revert this
mostly cosmetic change to get the gate flowing again.

Change-Id: If06efd6b5378c1a268c432f98d200c7a2b525ac5
Related-Bug: #1741275
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Rename duplicated class name AttachVolumeMultiAttachTest"

This reverts commit fdee065bc8a2309965a51d9f24e624dfd088f9bd.

There has been a spike in volume test failures since this
change merged on March 13th due to scheduling failures in
Cinder with the CapacityFilter, presumably because the rename
caused too many volume tests to be running concurrently on
the same host.

Until we have a better solution, like potentially bumping
the size of the volume group in devstack, we can revert this
mostly cosmetic change to get the gate flowing again.

Change-Id: If06efd6b5378c1a268c432f98d200c7a2b525ac5
Related-Bug: #1741275

commit_message:
Wire up --skip-tags to the overcloud upgrade cli

This is already wired into the ansible-action [1] so this review just
adds skip_tags to the update_nodes workflow which calls that
action. There is a related review in the tripleoclient
Ie7fb8d9a388c6d53a31800406b03ddb8ed426401 that exposes
--skip-tags to the operator and passes it here, and that review
will depend on this one.

[1]  https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blob/4739027b9eaf3dc895b29b67dbca0ffc79b36d4b/tripleo_common/actions/ansible.py#L259
Change-Id: I8544de64d3307e3dc925c1cecf2d9156e31d25a8
(cherry picked from commit dcc73a9856ec10605439fff88f945a6642afd36c)

commit_message:
Add disable_selinux_do_reboot variable

This allows the user to control whether hosts will be rebooted to apply
an SELinux policy configuration change. We cannot do this in CI, where
the Ansible control host is the host being configured.

Change-Id: I431ed26d907a534e2e99a8032152340d109fd49e

commit_message:
Update README & CONTRIBUTING for OpenStack process

Kayobe is to become an OpenStack-related project, and as such will use
Gerrit for code reviews and Storyboard for issue and feature tracking.
The README and CONTRIBUTING documents have been updated to reflect that,
and a standard OpenStack HACKING document has been added.

Change-Id: Id03bcb5183bfbf6e84bb4d9c22f85d9418b6b4fc
Story: #2001637
Task: #6644

commit_message:
Use pbr to build the project

Python Build Reasonableness (PBR) [1] is used by most OpenStack projects
for building python packages, so we should fall into line here.

[1] https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pbr

Change-Id: Ic74a62eeb65e7158ce75a082e68652c2e50a2a91
Story: #2001637
Task: #6648

commit_message:
Create vhost_socket_dir with proper permissions

For ovs2.8 version, it is required to modify the vhost socket
directory permissions as openvswitch:hugetlbfs instead of
qemu:qemu. Create the dir and assign it proper permissions in
step 3.

Change-Id: I5fc2f852c66c2b825af96aba2657d0f9085dc8c3

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-09 11:53:27.000000000', 'message': "Use stestr for running unit tests, add a coverage environment

stestr [1] is a fork of the testrunner python test runner.

Coverage tests can be run using 'tox -e cover'.

Adds a job for checking coverage to Zuul check and gate.

[1] http://stestr.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

Change-Id: I25cd407677a4013d022f87d124c6db43ab6bb2e0
Story: #2001637
Task: #6648
"}]
commit_message:
Use stestr for running unit tests, add a coverage environment

stestr [1] is a fork of the testrunner python test runner.

Coverage tests can be run using 'tox -e cover'.

Adds a job for checking coverage to Zuul check and gate.

[1] http://stestr.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

Change-Id: I25cd407677a4013d022f87d124c6db43ab6bb2e0
Story: #2001637
Task: #6648

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-24 20:32:53.000000000', 'message': "WIP: New-style _set_inventory_for_provider

Given the UUID of a provider, set the inventory records for the provider
to the supplied dict of resources.

Compare and contrast with the existing set_inventory_for_provider, which
was created for the simpler get_inventory code path from the resource
tracker.

This one is specially formulated for use by update_from_provider_tree,
because from there, whereas we DO need to _ensure_resource_class(), we
ALSO want to short out if inv_data matches what's already cached, but we
DON'T want to:
- _ensure_resource_provider
- refresh_and_get_inventory
- DELETE if inventory is empty, else PUT
- retry
- invalidate the cache on failure

This version is more in the spirit of set_traits_for_provider.

Change-Id: I45f1df6ca5618f76337319ba225493625a5ee2d6
WIP: Test

commit_message:
New-style _set_inventory_for_provider

Given the UUID of a provider, set the inventory records for the provider
to the supplied dict of resources.

Compare and contrast with the existing set_inventory_for_provider, which
was created for the simpler get_inventory code path from the resource
tracker.

This one is specially formulated for use by update_from_provider_tree,
because from there, whereas we DO need to _ensure_resource_class(), we
ALSO want to short out if inv_data matches what's already cached, but we
DON'T want to:
- _ensure_resource_provider
- refresh_and_get_inventory
- DELETE if inventory is empty, else PUT
- retry
- invalidate the cache on failure

This version is more in the spirit of set_traits_for_provider.

Change-Id: I45f1df6ca5618f76337319ba225493625a5ee2d6
blueprint: update-provider-tree
